title: How Bridget's Lover Escaped
text:
How Bridget's Lover Escaped (), also known as Le Mariage de Victoire, is a 1907 French <a href="short%20film">short</a> <a href="silent%20film">silent</a> <a href="comedy%20film">comedy film</a> directed by <a href="Georges%20M%C3%A9li%C3%A8s">Georges Méliès</a>.
Production.
The cast includes <a href="Fernande%20Albany">Fernande Albany</a> as the cook (Victorine in the French release of the film, Bridget in the American version), and the actor Manuel as her fiancé the fireman. The scene outside the house was <a href="location%20filming">filmed outdoors</a>, using Méliès's own house in <a href="Montreuil%2C%20Seine-Saint-Denis">Montreuil, Seine-Saint-Denis</a>.
The film includes examples of <a href="substitution%20splice">substitution splicing</a>, as well as two experimental techniques relatively rare in Méliès's films: a three-scene <a href="cross-cutting">cross-cutting</a> sequence, and a <a href="medium%20shot">medium shot</a> used to give the audience a final glimpse of the cook and her fiancé.
Release.
The film was released by Méliès's <a href="Star%20Film%20Company">Star Film Company</a> and is numbered 929–935 in its catalogues. It was registered for American copyright at the <a href="Library%20of%20Congress">Library of Congress</a> on 26 April 1907. The film's release was first advertised in the press on 1 July 1907, in the "Phono-Ciné-Gazette".
An unedited print of the film on <a href="16mm">16mm</a> stock survives at the Library of Congress.
